user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 14.3.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The for-loop controlling expression uses sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids):
for (offset = 0; offset < sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids); ++offset)

The value of sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids) is invariant (a compile-time size of the array member) and does not change during loop execution. This makes the loop's controlling expression invariant and therefore violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Neither exception (an intentional infinite loop, nor the allowed do-while constant-false case) applies here.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/1829.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl:
```c
static int32 OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(int *os_maxfd, fd_set *os_set, const OS_FdSet *OSAL_set)
{
    size_t       offset;
    size_t       bit;
    osal_index_t id;
    uint8        objids;
    int          osfd;
    int32        status;

    status = OS_SUCCESS;
    for (offset = 0; offset < sizeof(OSAL_set->object_ids); ++offset)
    {
        objids = OSAL_set->object_ids[offset];
        bit    = 0;
        while (objids != 0)
        {
            id = OSAL_INDEX_C((offset * 8) + bit);
            if ((objids & 0x01) != 0 && id < OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES)
            {
                osfd = OS_impl_filehandle_table[id].fd;
                if (osfd >= 0)
                {
                    if (osfd >= FD_SETSIZE || !OS_impl_filehandle_table[id].selectable)
                    {
                        /* out of range of select() implementation */
                        status = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
                    }
                    else
                    {
                        FD_SET(osfd, os_set);
                        if (osfd > *os_maxfd)
                        {
                            *os_maxfd = osfd;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
            ++bit;
            objids >>= 1;
        }
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
